speakeroldname: Mr. Peter Milliken (Kingston and the Islands):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, when the House adjourned at 1 p.m. I was decrying the evils of the bill the government has intro-

February 18, 1992

duced before the House. The bill itself does not have anything offensive in it. It is just a silly and ridiculous piece of legislation. Frankly as I have indicated before, it is a complete waste of the time of the House.
One of the principal reasons I put forward for the House's consideration as to why the bill is so ridiculous is the holes that it leaves, in what it claims to be its efforts to control government expenditure. There are two principal omissions from this legislation. First, the legislation does not control interest payments on the public debt. Those interest payments are allowed to go unchecked.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: Order please. I ask the collaboration of all members in this House. The public wants to listen to the intervention of the hon. member.

Frankly, I am pleased that there are members here. At least there are some ministers here now. There were none this morning during my speech. I am delighted that they have re-appeared. Obviously my words have inspired them to greater efforts.
The interest payments on the public debt are excluded from the consideration of this bill. If the interest payments on the public debt go out of control because the government raises interest rates, they are not subject to the over-all government expenditure plan. The deficit could increase out of control every year if interest rates take off and the government is forced to pay more interest on the public debt, or if the government runs up the deficit as it has in the past and forces the interest amounts to increase.
It is fine to say the government has no responsibility for that. With great respect, it does have considerable responsibility for it. If the government was serious about putting a cap on government expenditures, surely it would include interest payments on the public debt, particularly when those interest payments constitute the largest single expense the government has. My recollection is that the government is paying out $38 billion a year. Perhaps my colleague for Sudbury can confirm that figure. I believe it is the interest figure being paid annually by the government at this stage.
$43 billion.

My friend for St. Boniface suggests that maybe it is $43 billion. Whatever it is, it is a very substantial figure. Those amounts are not subject to any spending restraints under this bill.
Government Orders
This is for restraint of government expenditures but it only applies to certain expenditures. The biggest single one is excluded. The government says it cannot take any responsibility for that, although the responsibility is direct and four-square. It rests clearly on the shoulders of the government. It is charged with managing the Canadian economy, not the opposition, and yet it says it cannot be responsible for that and will exclude it from the bill.
That is the first serious weakness in the bill. It indicates how silly and ridiculous it is for the government to bring forward this kind of legislation in this House. I am glad to see my colleague from Willowdale agrees.
The second aspect of this bill which is so silly is the lack of control on tax expenditures. Members may ask what tax expenditures are. The government may give a tax break to a group in order to induce some particular aspect of the Canadian economy. For example a special writeoff may be given on the development of a gold mine. Those operating the gold mine will not have to pay taxes during a certain development period, and obviously the government will forgo revenue. That is called a tax expenditure. The government gives up its right to tax the gold mine and bring in revenue it might otherwise get.
By introducing its budget the government says that it will give a preferential tax break to certain people in order to induce them to spend their money in a particular way.
It may give a child tax credit, for example, to those who have children to either encourage them to have children, or to assist them in paying the costs of looking after the children.
The tax break is a tax expenditure. It is giving away or forgoing revenue in order to achieve a desired result. This is all perfectly proper, but if you have a cap on expenditures, why would you not also cap tax expenditures?
Yet the government has left itself a free hand to spend the tax dollars that it does not actually bring in. It is saying in this bill that it will limit the amount of tax dollars it spends on everything except the public debt, but will not in any way restrict its right to forgo tax dollars and not bring them into the pot.

February 18, 1992
Government Orders
In other words, give tax breaks to its wealthy friends, the Tory fat cats. They are the same people who got the tax break when this government took office and have been getting them all along ever since. That is what the government is proposing to do. It is saying it is not going to be hamstrung in any way by legislation in the House of Commons that restricts its ability to give those tax breaks, in other words to make tax expenditures.
If the government was serious about controlling government expenditures, surely it would deal with that issue in a straightforward and responsible way and include that in the bill. It has chosen not to do so.
The third argument against this silly legislation, this ridiculous bill, was made by the minister himself. The poor minister stood there, and really he must have been very embarrassed to have to introduce this kind of legislation in the House.
Yet his argument was that if any government wants to change this in future, when it introduces its budget making the change, it will have to introduce an amendment to this act as well. Imagine, what could be simpler?
If you do not like the restrictions in the bill, you introduce your budget proposing higher expenditures and in the budget you announce there will be changes to this bill. It happens every day in every budget.
The government announces that there will be tax changes. It announces the tax changes in the budget and then it introduces a bill to amend the Income Tax Act. That is all it is going to do with this bill. It is exactly the same thing.
This is nothing but a scam as the hon. member for Broadview-Greenwood so ably says. This is ridiculous. It is silly and it should not be allowed.
The ministers of the Crown who have an obligation to be here and participate in debate absent themselves from this Chamber when government bills are under discussion. It is a national disgrace.
If they are going to bring in silly bills like this, the least they can do is sit here and listen to the debate. They choose to absent themselves in their entirety, 39 of them. It is wrong. They have an obligation as members of this House to sit here when government legislation is under consideration.
If they are going to propose something so stupid, the least they can do is listen to the debate.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: I should just like to point out to the hon. member that the presence or absence of members is always a touchy issue and that his remark could apply to member on both sides of this House this morning. I think you would have to agree that when we have close to 3 million people in this country out of work and the fishery plants are closing down in Atlantic Canada, it can be very frustrating when you get a sense that the government is not listening to anything we say on this side of the House.

Mr. Speaker, I have three questions which I will try to answer. My first question is: What is the exact nature of this bill? My second: Why is it being tabled today? And my third: Are there alternatives to the solutions proposed by the government?

What is C-56? On the surface it states it will control the expenditures over five years to an average increase of 3 per cent. That is what the paper says. I find it really astonishing that it talks about the control of expenditures, and that is important, but it does not set any deficit or debt targets. With the deficit and the debt being as serious a problem as it is today and the fact that they talk about it often is something that I would have believed they would have attacked in this particular piece of legislation, that they would have tried to do something about it.
Why is the government introducing this particular piece of legislation, this control on expenditures? On paper it looks really good. Perhaps the government believes that the Canadian public will believe that this is really going to make a difference. Is it really a serious effort? If it is such a good idea, why was it not introduced sooner? The Conservatives have been in power for seven years or so. Or, is it nothing perhaps but smoke and mirrors, a lot of glitz, propaganda to try to make people believe that finally they have taken control of things? They have not taken control of things. They have not. The government is actually reaping what it has sowed. What has it sowed?
We know that there was a made-in-Canada recession. The Prime Minister indicated that. We know that there has been a continued high dollar. We know that interest rates have been extremely high. They have come down a bit, but the real interest rate, the difference between inflation and the actual interest rate, is still really

That should have saved it some money. We know that the debt is in excess of $400 billion. There is an interesting dialogue, debate, discussion about the interest rate.
I want to introduce into my address today a direct quote from an answer from the former minister of finance, the present Minister for International Trade, to my question as to what the debt really was at the end of the fiscal year that they came into power. I read for the fiscal year 1983-84 the figure for the national debt at the end of that year was $167,985 million. I want to read that into the record because of the debate as to what it really was. Some people like to exaggerate, to suggest that perhaps the fact that it is more than double is not nearly as serious a matter as a lot of people would like to pretend it is. It is a serious matter. It has more than doubled. It has more than doubled because the government underestimated the impact. Surely when you buy a company and it has a debt, you fold that into your planning. You make sure that you take that into consideration. You do not go forward and behave as if you had no debt. When the Conservatives took over government they should have done the same thing.
It is also interesting to note that Canada's debt is growing faster than all of the G-7 countries with the exception of Italy. That should be troubling for all of us who are really quite concerned. We should note as well that the debt service charges as a percentage of our gross domestic productivity has continually increased since this government took office.I think that is an accurate statement. I have checked it out and I am told that it is. Obviously that is a serious matter as well.
What is it that it has done to try to control expenditures besides bring in this piece of legislation today. You and I both know that it has been off-loading in a massive kind of way to the provinces. We have talked often about off-loading health, education and social assistance programs. In fact, just recently it was talking about a particular bill that dealt with the capping of social assistance to the provinces of British Columbia, Alberta and Ontario.
I have mentioned time and time again in this House that between the years 1986 and 1995, almost a decade, there would be 30 billion fewer dollars transferred to provinces for health and education matters. I find that shocking in spite of these massive reductions, these cuts, the slashing that the deficit is still where it was for the last 6, 7, 8, 9, 10 years and the debt has more than doubled.
We have to take it in the context of the revenue as well. If you owe a certain amount of money, the next natural question is how much do you earn, what are your assets? It is rather interesting to note that the government's revenue since it came into power has increased by roughly $60 billion. It is not far from doubling its revenue. The obvious question is where has all Canadians' money, in the form of taxes, gone? In spite of these massive tax increases, 34 with the goods and services tax, an increase of $60 billion roughly in revenue, the deficit is roughly at the same position and the debt has more than doubled. We are losing ground in spite of the fact that we are paying more and more.
The government, in introducing this legislation, will cite the U.S. experience with similar types of legislation. I would like to draw attention to two or three points. First of all, we have different systems of government. Virtually everyone is aware of that. The legislation is significantly different. What is not well known, and what has not been repeated often, is that this U.S. legislation has not been terribly successful. The U.S. has had to go back and adjust its targets in order to make them fit its estimates, and so on.
To try and give people some reassurance is the thing to do when they are upset about the deficit and the debt. In terms of what it will actually accomplish, there are serious doubts in my mind and in the minds of many
February 18, 1992

people who have studied this legislation, looked at the critiques and have thought about the legislation.
I repeat that the government's intention, at least on paper, is to control the expenditures. It may or may not do that. I am not trying to suggest that the government has simply done this and that in order to try to fool people, but there is an element of that. I am troubled by that.
This bill says nothing about the possibility of giving tax concessions to friends, and I say friends in the broadest sense of the term. It could create a number of loopholes that would still favour individuals, that would still contradict or counteract some of those expenditure controls that are in place. That is really unfortunate. I should point out that not only is this my criticism, but government members of the finance committee have raised this same point.
The government imposes limits on spending based upon certain assumptions being made right now, obviously. We see this in the control of spending over five years to an average of 3 per cent, as I indicated initially. It has to make assumptions about inflation, interest rates and unemployment rates. Those are three variables, and there are probably others.
If we were to go back and review the assumptions and the predictions that were made in previous exercises, we would find that the targets were way, way off. The targets did not resemble reality once that reality came to be. If that is correct, we need to ask a couple of other questions. What should give us confidence that those predictions, those assumptions that the government has to make will be better than those of the past? There is no evidence to that effect. If you build a model based on certain assumptions, how can you have confidence in that model? You really cannot.
Therefore, I am led to that great suspicion that this looks good, sounds good and is going to fool some people, but really will do nothing to attack the root problems of the deficit, the debt and the economic situation that is troubling Canadians today; a very serious one indeed.
I want to point out as well that there is a possibility, and I can assure you that others have thought about it, that the government could go on a spending binge. We are very close to an election, we all know that. It could be weeks, months or perhaps a year away. The government

could make a number of promises, recognizing that if it were re-elected, it would have to deal with it and it would do so as best it could. It could make those promises, recognizing that it might not be re-elected, and really stick it to the party that forms the next government.

We need to state very honestly what needs to be done with the deficit and debt, and where we are going to get the funds to address the serious overspending. Mr. Speaker, you will recall that a month ago, the leader of my party, the Hon. Jean Chretien, proposed a long-term recovery program. I would like to remind my colleagues of these proposals:
Rebuild the industrial fabric of Canada by slowing disindustrialization; by bridging the gap between Canadian and American interest rates, in particular real interest rates, and by lowering the value of the Canadian dollar. We also asked for a fair fiscal policy.
Third, to implement effective retraining programs.
Fourth, to ensure a more balanced economic growth.

However, I am well aware that some people have already spent enough time in a bureaucratic environment to know very well that this effort, this initiative, will look very good and that it might even fool some people and make them believe that this a substantial measure. Yet, in the end you will see that the achievement will be a rather small one.

Mr. Speaker, I want to thank my colleague from Broadview-Greenwood for a question that is extremely important.
There are several dimensions to his question that I want to respond to. The first one is, yes, we need to find money to respond to people's needs today because those individuals who are not being served cost the state money. They are on unemployment insurance, on social assistance, or on some other government program that does not help them very often to get back into the work force. It is a drain, and I do not say that in the pejorative sense. They are entitled to a quality of life, but at the same time the possibilities of significant quality are not great under the current circumstances for many of them. Yes, we need to respond.
What happens very often is that a certain number of dollars are put forward and people believe those dollars are going to respond to need. It is very difficult to predict how much is going to be required. We need to make predictions, but at the same time if we have underestimated or overestimated we need to respond in kind.
It is morally wrong for any man or woman who is willing to work, who is willing to take a retraining program, not to be accepted into a program immediately. One cannot wait six, nine or twenty-four months. It is not right. It is unfair. It does not resolve the problem. They are demoralized even more. They are made to believe that they cannot fit in. Mr. Speaker, I find it somewhat strange that the former chairman of the Standing Committee on Finance is asking that question.
He knows very well that if the will were there, the government would not need that bill, a bill respecting the control of government expenditures.
We have a parliamentary democracy and the majority carries. In 1984,1 would like to remind the hon. member from Mississauga, the revenues of the government were $70 billion and the expenditures were $109 billion.

Mr. Speaker, I hope Canadians who are watching and listening to this debate will have listened to the interjections of the last two members and have seen just how this issue of debt and deficit can be viewed in a black and white manner. Some members of this Chamber are accusing the government of having spent its way into massive problems, and other members are chastising the government for attempting to curb its own spending. I hope Canadians recognize very clearly that a lot of rhetoric goes on in this Chamber.
I would like to speak briefly to this bill. I start by reviewing for Canadians very briefly what it is we are debating, what this piece of legislation is intended to do. Essentially this bill will put a limit on federal program spending between fiscal year 1991-92 and fiscal year
February 18, 1992

1995-96. I am personally pleased to be able to speak to this bill. I am delighted that it is in this Chamber. I am delighted that the government accepted it and that it is on its way to becoming the law of the land. I say that because I personally lobbied the Minister of Finance in order to try to get legislation of exactly this nature.
As part of the budget of a year ago, this legislation was brought in to provide control on federal spending so that the deficit of the Government of Canada could be reduced and we could start tackling the level of debt that has been built up in this country. To make sure that spending is restrained, the budget proposed this bill which says that by law the Government of Canada has to restrain its spending. I think this is a very significant point. We are removing from my hands as a member of Parliament and the hands of my colleagues in the Chamber the opportunity, the possibility, the power to increase spending in a runaway fashion.
A draft version of the bill has been reviewed by the House. It went to committee where it was tightened up. A few changes were made, I think for the better. What the bill essentially says to Canadians now is: "Listen, you are going to get a guarantee on spending from this government, because the law says that higher taxes cannot be used to finance higher spending and that new programs will have to be funded within the total amount of money the government already has". That is pretty significant.
The budget that came down a year ago was essentially a budget with a guarantee. We have a guarantee in this bill that the government has limits placed on how much it can spend. We know exactly what those are going to be for the next five years. Taxpayers have a guarantee that the government is not going to revert to the bad old days of runaway spending.
Second, in that budget the government created the debt servicing and reduction fund which was a new national bank account. Consider it a national personal savings account.
The third guarantee was that all the extra revenue above what was collected and the taxes it replaced, all those extra GST revenues, were going to be placed into this new national bank account and used solely for the reduction of the federal deficit. It was a budget with a
Government Orders
guarantee and it was something quite radical. We had not really seen that kind of budget before.
Over the past 20 years we saw the usual dance of finance ministers who came along and gave us a lot of projections and a lot of promises and there was nothing behind them. There was no teeth. There was no legislation. There was nothing forcing them to obtain their goals and targets. Nothing like this bill has come before this House before. It is radical and significant and different.
In order to maintain the integrity of Canada's social programs and to help people in need, there have to be some exemptions from restraint on spending and this bill is no exception to that. There will be exemptions for emergencies such as unexpected flooding. Self-financing programs like unemployment insurance are exempted because they are just that, self-funding.
The real kicker in this particular bill is the provision for overspending. Let's say that members of this House decide to defy the law. Let's say that we vote on legislation which pushes spending over. Let's say we approve a budget that the Minister of Finance brings in that violates the spirit of this. If overspending occurs, what happens then? We owe it to Canadian taxpayers to explore this. If the government spends more than it said it would, what is going to happen?
This bill will put into law that if spending exceeds the limit for any one year, the amount of that overspending has to be made up through spending cuts within two years. It is simple and straightforward, a very direct concept. If the government spends too much in one year and violates the law then in each of the other two years it has to cut. That only makes sense.
In terms of compliance, the finance minister would not be allowed to present a budget that is inconsistent with the act and the annual public accounts would contain a statement saying that they conform to the act.
As a third guarantee we get the Auditor General involved. The Auditor General reports to Parliament on whether or not the act has been complied with.
That is what we are debating. That is exactly what this legislation proposes, and I for one support it but not blindly. I would like to tell the House why I support it. I do not support it just because I am a member of the political party that is forming the government now. It is very close to some of the reasons I wanted to be in this place, why I wanted to be in Parliament. I believe the

people are saying it is time they had more of an impact on the system. It is time some of the authority and power of politicians to spend their money as taxpayers was removed. It is time there was a constraint, a system, a structure, a mechanism, some form, guarantee, promise, or hope they will have as taxpayers, that the people who go to Ottawa and become members of Parliament do not waste money and overspend. I remember a year and a half ago travelling to a small town in southern Ontario called Blenheim. The folks in Blenheim got fed up with property taxes that were going up for one reason or another. It was mostly because of the usual problems we have in this country with too many levels of government, too much overlap and duplication, too many governments trying to do the same thing with one set of taxpayers' pockets and five sets of taxes. We only need to look at two sets of school buses rumbling down the road to see that. We only need to look at the road grader that starts at one county garage and goes down to the town line, and the other country road grader comes up to meet it.
It is only common sense and the people in Blenheim saw that. They saw it there at highway 401 where there were four garages beside each other, one for the province, one for the county, one for the municipality and one for who knows what. They saw all that. They looked at their property tax bills which had gone up 200 per cent in some cases. They said that was enough. They withheld their taxes. It is a pretty radical thing to do. You can do it with property taxes but you cannot with other levels of taxation. People struck back.
I went to Blenheim and spent a day there at the high school auditorium. I met with people to try to find out why they did this. It was pretty radical stuff. What did they propose for other levels of government? What did they think ought to be the solutions? The people were eloquent, articulate and simple in their response. They said there were too many governments and too many sets of taxes. There was too much waste and inefficiency and
the governments were without controls and mechanisms of accountability.
Do you know what? They were right. We do. That is why I can support this kind of legislation which gives us a structure, a ceiling, a roof on the kind of spending we are capable of doing.
That little experience in Blenheim, Ontario has been interesting, and I have been following it for several months. Out of it was created an organization called the Ontario Taxpayers Coalition. The last time I talked to the organizers several tens of thousands of people had joined. The interesting thing about the organization is that it is not composed of the usual kind of protesters we see out on the lawn of Parliament Hill. They are average middle class folks who are a little bit scared of what they are doing and not quite sure what to do next. They do not know much about mobilizing and do not have any organizers. They are generally plain, ordinary Canadian taxpayers who have come together to try to send a message to us, the politicians; the political leaders at the municipal, federal, provincial and regional levels.
Part of the message I think is concerned with this bill. I think they like this. I think the people want it. I think the people are asking for more of that. I have heard the same in my own riding at town hall meetings where people stood up night after night and asked why we don't have a balanced budget; why we don't have some sort of rules somewhere that say the government cannot go into debt; why we don't have something in the Constitution that says you shall have a balanced budget within a certain period of time.
My hon. friend across the way is hollering at me that this does not answer those questions. I will admit that. But what I see here is a very large and powerful step on that path. I really see a government attempt to try to move in that direction.
The questions are in my mail too. I get them when I travel and from the people I visit and talk to at town hall meetings. Let me read you a little bit of my mail. This is from William McGrath of Acton, Ontario: "We must cut programs to control spending. We have become a welfare state. Our children will pay for this folly".
February 18, 1992

Arthur Dixon in Cheltenham: "Reduce the deficit. I would pay my own share and that of my family in the shortest time if I believed we could really achieve it".
Harold Denny from Acton, Ontario: "Government should do the same as all private business is doing and tighten its belt until it really hurts. We have to cut our spending to the very bone and eliminate all frills, credit, etc. just to survive the recession. It will be a long, tough struggle. I know, because I started to work in the depression of the thirties, but it can be done".
Kevin Gray in Burlington: "The number one way in which everyone's future will look promising is to get the deficit under control, if not obliterated. It just isn't fair to the upcoming generation. Something eventually has to give".
Stan McNeice of Bolton, Ontario: "Living in the greatest and wealthiest country, Canada, can only be protected if our news media, newspapers, TV and radio people could be educated into the dangers of the debt and be given some happy thoughts instead of all the sad ones". That is an interesting suggestion.
Amel Ranger from Acton, Ontario: "My future, my family's future, and Canada's future are all headed for a big fall. We have all lived beyond our means for too many years. It is now pay-back time. Greed, jealousy and envy have put us where we are today".
Catherine McDonald, Caledon East: "Eliminate some levels of government. Reduce the number of politicians at every level. Reduce the number of grants to "do good" agencies. We don't need to be coddled from the cradle to the grave. Reduce defence, reduce the deficit".
A. L. Campagnolo, Caledon East: "If things continue the way they are going, I see Canada becoming a third world country with all the consequences for my family. Unless the government starts governing the way it should; learning to say 'no'; stops spending the money it does not have; starts repaying the principal on the deficit, we shall not have a future to speak of. We need statesmen, not politicians, and we need them to make tough decisions which people will understand. Free trade may be one of them, but it is not the only one of them, certainly not in its present form".

Norman Klenman from Ganges, British Columbia: "There is simply no practical alternative. The Prime Minister, the cabinet and the caucus are doing manful work in terrible times. There is simply no money to spend on programs and initiatives which might earn popularity".
J. W. Cargill from Bolton, Ontario: "I will feel happier when Canada starts living within its means. We have nothing for that rainy day and are being forced to borrow more and more against the future. With close to half the national debt owing to foreigners, it's pretty scary".
Finally, from Betty Sherman in Terra Cotta, Ontario: "Until a way can be found to reinculcate such values as self-reliance, responsibility, pride of workmanship and recognition of individual merit in Canadian attitudes, I cannot find much real optimism about turning the country around. Prospects in Ontario under a socialist government are even especially more discouraging. A lessening of government intrusion in our lives might help to restore some incentive, if it is not already too late".
Those are a lot of different voices coming from a lot of different Canadians. They are all taxpayers, and all want the government to spend less and not more.
I might just quickly address the reasons some of my colleagues across the way do not want this bill to be put into place and state their opposition to it. This particular piece of legislation would restrict government spending and hold down the increases in government spending for five long years. Some of the people on the other side of this Chamber believe the government will change at the next election and they will be on this side. I don't pretend to know what is going to happen, but I do know that Canadians will finally have a guarantee that whatever happens to the government; whatever the complexion of this Parliament is after the next election; whatever bunch of people the taxpayers send to Ottawa to run Canada, spend Canada's money and put money in Canada's bank account; will have to live by a law that says they cannot overspend. That is pretty simple. That is what this bill says. We will have a law that says members of Parliament cannot overspend any more. If we had this law over the last 10 years we would not be in the situation we are in now. Whether deficits were run up in

Government Orders
years past for good reasons or bad, whether the social causes were valid or frivolous does not matter. They were run up, they existed and the deficit got to where it was affecting our debt so much that today we are crippled with $40 billion of interest every year on the debt. If the law had been in place, we would not have the mess today. If this law is put into place, I am sure we will have fewer messes tomorrow and in the years that come.
Those people on the other side do not want the bill because, I gather, they do not want to be constrained and have limits put on the government's ability to spend; a government they feel they might form.
We are in changed times. We are in the 90s now. We are in a time where we face a whole new set of demands, pressures and challenges, quite unlike things that faced Canada before. We all know the world is becoming globalized in terms of trade and world economy. We know there is competition around the globe for capital. They sure need a lot of it in eastern Europe and Russia. They need a lot of it around the world. We need a lot of it. We need $40 billion a year to pay the interest on the debt. Globalization and the search for capital and competitiveness is very concerning. We must get more competitive and we will never become competitive while 30, 35 or 40 cents of every taxpayer's dollar is dissipated in interest payments on the debt.
The 90s demand something different and I think what they demand from a lot of us is what the 1860s demanded of a lot of Americans. I would like to end this with a few words of a man who was very hated within his time. But he was a great man and knew how to read what his country needed then. I think it is what our country needs today. This is what Abraham Lincoln said:
You cannot bring about prosperity by discouraging thrift. You cannot strengthen the weak by weakening the strong. You cannot help little men by tearing down big men. You cannot help the wage earner by tearing down the wage payer. You cannot further brotherhood of man by encouraging class hatred. You cannot help the poor by destroying the rich. You cannot establish sound security on borrowed money. You cannot keep out of trouble by spending more than you earn. You cannot build character and courage by taking away man's initiative and independence and you cannot help men permanently by doing for them what they should, and could do for themselves.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter Milliken (Kingston and the Islands):
speechtext:
I would like to ask the hon. member a question. He seems very strong on this bill. I am not sure why because I think if he had listened to my speech, he would have realized the
serious deficiencies in the legislation. He keeps claiming this bill is somehow going to solve Canada's deficit problems. All the letters from his constituents dealt with that, but the bill in fact, as he must recognize, does absolutely nothing to help the deficit since it can be changed at every opportunity.
I looked through the bill and it is quite a short one. I was looking for the enforcement mechanism. The hon. member says this bill will force governments to do this or to do that. Well, almost every bill I have seen has a provision in it that if there is a violation of the bill, if the provision is breached in any way, the offender is then brought before a court and either fined or imprisoned.
I looked in vain for any clause that would put the Minister of Finance in the slammer if he violated this bill. I wonder if the hon. member would be prepared to vote against the bill at second reading to ensure that an amendment was made to it providing that a Minister of Finance who operated in breach of the legislation would in fact suffer some penalty. Perhaps all the members of the cabinet could suffer some penalty, like resigning, because if we had such a provision in this bill when it was passed in 1984, this government would have been out long ago. We would probably have a better government in Canada today. Would he agree to an amendment like that to this bill?

Of course not. It is not criminal legislation. It is legislation which puts constraints on the spending limits of the government.
The bill, in declaring fairly categorically that if overspending occurred one year spending cuts would have to be made in the following two years to make up for that, is a pretty decent start.

I was listening with interest to the hon. member when he was speaking. He was reading all those letters from his constituents telling him that we should cut spending.
The government of this day, the government that was elected in 1984, has spent more than any other government in Canadian history in the shortest period of time. The debt at that point in 1984 was $180 billion and now it is $400 billion.
What is very interesting is that the foreign debt was very low. But now 25 per cent of Canada's debt is owed to foreign banks, to the International Monetary Fund, to
February 18, 1992	COMMONS
the World Bank and other bankers. So really our situation has deteriorated.
I am wondering why at the end of its second mandate suddenly the government side sees the light and says that it has to cut spending. It had the opportunity to have better managed the economy. It has not done so and now it brings us a bill that is full of loopholes. This bill does not mean anything.
I would like to ask the member just one question because he talked so much about the need for people to have input.
For instance, Switzerland has binding referendums on any legislation. Would he be in favour that in Canada we establish a binding referendum? If people were not happy they could have a referendum and say to the government that it is overspending or that it should do this or that. Is he in favour of such legislation?

In terms of the numbers my hon. friend quotes, I would just like to clarify what is the financial situation of the government.
In 1984, the government was spending $16 billion a year more on programs than it was taking in in taxes. That has been reduced through tax increases and financial management to the point where $16 billion in the hole for program spending has now been turned into a $12 billion surplus on program spending. From $16 billion in the hole, spending more than we took in, we now take in $12 billion more than we spend on programs.

speakerposition: Deputy Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext: How do you explain the deficit?

I will explain the deficit, so listen very carefully to this.
There is a $12 billion surplus this year, yet the interest on the debt is $42 billion. Take $42 billion on the debt interest, remove $12 billion of it because that is our operating surplus this year and we end up with net requirements of $30 billion which is roughly the deficit. We still have a deficit because our surplus is not yet big enough to pay all the interest on the debt.
So Canadians can ask: When is the government's surplus going to be enough to pay all the interest on the debt? That is the real question. When the government has enough surplus to pay the interest, we have no more

Government Orders
deficit. When is that going to happen? We will find out next Tbesday in the budget.
But the projections at this point are that in fiscal year 1994-95 we have zero deficit because we have got enough in surplus tax revenues to be able to handle all the interest payments on the debt.
It is simple. It is like having a mortgage, not making enough money to make the mortgage payments, and going further into debt. That is the situation Canada has been in for years.
But when there is enough income and finally the mortgage payments can be paid, then you are not going into debt any more. That is where we are leading. That is the most important point and it is amazing how the members opposite lose interest once you start to explain it.

Mr. Speaker, I have listened to that explanation with a lot of interest.
One thing that the hon. member would have to agree with is that that explanation and that answer is very different from the commitment that they made to the Canadian people in 1984.
They did not say they would reduce program expenditures below taxation. They did not give the kind of complicated explanations that he has just given now to justify patting himself and his Minister of Finance on the back.
They said that they would reduce the deficit. What Canadians understood from that was that the deficit would be lower as a result of electing a Conservative government than it had been before. It is higher.
The question I want to ask the hon. member is this. Suppose the government as the next election approaches comes up with a fancy new idea that will cost a lot of money and thinks will help it get re-elected.
This so-called limit I ask the member, is this not legislation of restraint? Is this not something that can be covered in one simple clause in an amending bill on day care or some other new program the government might decide to do?
Can it not do away with this so-called limitation it is imposing on itself just by having one small paragraph in that new piece of legislation? Like the unemployment insurance bill or the other programs which are exempted, it would say that this new spending program

February 18, 1992
Government Orders
would be exempted. Can this bill not be circumvented by the government just as easily as that?

Mr. Speaker, the short answer is no. Any overspending has to be made up by spending cuts within two years.
In error, I did not respond fully to my colleague across the way to the second part of his question which had to do with binding referenda.
He asked me whether I would support that or not. I have no problem with the concept of referenda. I do not think it would be particularly wise or economical to put every piece of legislation as he suggests to a vote by the Canadian people. Bear in mind the last federal election cost around $100 million.
