Mr. Speaker, I wanted to participate in the debate on this bill because it brings once again into the forefront of Canadian politics some ideas, some concepts. It is interesting to spend a moment or two looking at their origins.
This particular concept came out of the United States of America. I suppose in these days of free trade and integrating our two societies and integrating the economics of the two societies an inevitable step will be some integration of the political processes and how they go about trying to resolve the problems of the day.
There have been a lot of good things that have come out of California: surf-boards, hula hoops, Frisbees, all kinds of things.
One of the political ideas that has come out of the state of California is an idea called proposition 13. The background is pretty straightforward.
In many American legislatures anybody can walk in off the street and start the legislative process rolling. This can be wonderful democratically. It is not the worst idea in the world, but it has some consequences. We ought to review that a bit.
Anyone can walk in to any state legislature in America and say: "I want to produce a piece of legislation which says stop spending money". It can be as simple and as bald as that. Essentially that is the meaning of proposition 13.
When that is taken out to the population at large, it is pretty attractive. It is like saying: "There will be no bills arriving at your house this week". So they like that.
What they do not like is when the furnace does not work, when their services are not provided, when there is no electricity, when there are no cops on the beat, when their house catches fire and there are no fire-people to come and put out that fire. Then they get a little unhappy.
Those of us in public life sometimes have to explain to people there are many sides to a coin. It is not just a one-way street. There is a reason if the streets are full of potholes. A suitable solution is not to put out barriers which say that the street cannot be used anymore, because sooner or later one might have to. Even those who do not anticipate using that street may have to.
This idea in California produced a lot of bad side-effects. Unfortunately, for those people who were proponents of it, they did not have to stick around and explain the consequences later. That is one of the small flaws in this kind of a proposal.
It had some initial reaction and of course it showed up in the American Congress. It became a bill and the American Congress tried to do much the same thing.
To understand this one must have some sense of how Americans and the American governments put together pieces of legislation. The first thing people should know is that they do not always have to pass a budget for example.
February 18, 1992

The President is often upset with Congress, that it will not pass the budget he wants. But at the end of the day if it does not, he will have to spend the money anyway. So Congress often goes through many consecutive years without actually passing a budget and it does not have to pass all the budget bills.
In fact, almost any bill in the American Congress consists of one congressman who wants to say: "Let's all turn left", and another one who says: "Let's all turn right", and another one who says: "Let's go straight ahead", and another one who says: "Let's back up". If it passes the bill, the small little things that we might think are incongruent do not seem to matter. Doing something seems to matter.
That is part of the flaw that is contained in this legislation. If it were, as some members have proposed, a bill which said: "Okay, if the Minister of Finance of Canada spends more money than he is supposed to under a projection which we put in here, we will cut off his head," then perhaps we might be able to say with some surety: "Boy, he sure won't spend any more money than we have allocated in this bill". The bill does not say that. The bill goes, in a very straightforward way, I might add, along one avenue. It explores the legislative side.
What could the Parliament of Canada do in a legislative way to control spending? For some, that is a very attractive proposition, but what people have to understand is that this is not the only way in which governments spend money. This is, if I might categorize it, the theoretical way in which governments initiate new programs, establish laws and then proceed to spend money. But it is certainly not the only way.
Members who have been in this Chamber for a while will be well aware that there are lots of other avenues by which governments spend money and by which they continue to spend.
Part of the problem with this one is by putting a rather simplistic notion in place that you can take a single solitary number put it in law and that that will apply. That is like saying: "The trough is overflowing so we will shut of the tap". Well that may work to some degree, but the trough will still overflow for a while and the trough may not feed those who need it.
Government Orders
One has to get really simplistic to accept that this kind of a law can be passed.
The Americans in many of their state legislatures or at their Congress have tried this routine for some time. It has not been particularly successful there. I do not believe it stands much of a chance to be successful here for perhaps some slightly different reasons. But underlying it all is this one simple reason: This is not a task that has one solution; this is a task that has many.
I noticed the member for Halton-Peel was talking about the reaction of ordinary citizens to one barn being operated by the municipality and one by the province, and one bus system run by one school system and one by another, almost as if that never happens on the Hill, almost as if there is no duplication here.
Well, to use his same example, let us all adjourn for a moment and go and stand on the front steps. We can watch the little green buses roll around, then we can watch the little grey buses roll around, then we can watch all the little black limousines roll around, then we can watch all the cabbies roll around. Is that duplication?
Do I hear a great outcry in the Chamber today that maybe one bus system would provide transportation to everybody who works on the Hill? Oh, it is missing. Its silence is deafening. Maybe among the population there would be just a touch more of those who would believe this kind of legislation if they had not had their eyes opened for a little while.
That is the wonderfulness about this approach to it all. This makes eminent sense if you have never seen a government operate because you can hold up a piece of paper-here it is-you can say, as the member just did: "Here is the law, and the law says you cannot spend more than this".
By a quantum leap of faith, some would probably say: "You've done it". Deficits in financing have crucified governments for 100 years. Why did somebody else not think of doing it this way? For 100 years we have had deficits, expenditures and problems with financing. Why did nobody in the first century of politics pass a law like this? This would sure solve all the problems.
The reason is it does not. People who have been in government for a while at any level know that it does not, and people who are members of this House know that it will not. Worse yet-here is something I think we

February 18, 1992
Government Orders
should note-would be if every single member in this Chamber said: "Boy, this is it. I will stop every bill going through the door that exceeds the limit set in this bill".
Do you know what the end result would be for the people of Canada? Zip. The members in this Chamber, even I dare say the Minister of Finance and I will throw in the whole cabinet, are not the ones who spend the money. Sometimes they delude themselves into thinking that they do, always a dangerous practice. They are not the ones who run the day by day programs.
Even if they want to, even if they think they can, even if they get hard-nosed about it, they are small in number. There are thousands of people in our bureaucracy, in all different levels of government who are intelligent. There are smart people in control of programming who are saying every day: "You can pass any law you want. Give me 24 hours and I will provide you with the first run-through of how to get around that law. Provide me with the law that is the tightest law in the world and we will find a way to get around it".
If they are bright and particularly inventive some morning, they may even think up some new ways to get around the passage of laws like this. Rest assured, they will do it.
If a department head receives his or her status because of the number of people who are employed in the department, do you think that by having the same number of people in that department that you are going to stop expenditures? Even if the growth of that department was zero for a year, would the expenditures stay constant? Not on your life and you know that. That is part of the problem.
Some days I wish there was a law that would be passed which would get at the root of all this but I know better. That is the difficulty with putting this down on paper in quite this way. It is kind of like saying: "All you have to do is pass this bill and the problems are resolved". They are not and people know that. People in this Chamber even, busy folks that they are, know that.
More importantly, people across Canada know that. They have heard this song before. They have seen the dance. They know that governments that came into office pledging debt reduction did not do it. They did not
commit hara-kiri the morning after the first budget was tabled either. They managed to find some reason to struggle on.
This is a government that, in many ways, said it would stop spending money, and in some ways, it has. In other ways, it has not. When it wants to find money to spend, no matter what the laws are, it will find it. We all know that.
To be honest and straightforward, there should be an appendix to this bill which says: "Wait a minute, there is some fine print that goes along with this. There are some ways that governments do spend money and can spend money which will change this mix".
At the very outset, it ought to carry out some of the work that was carried out in the finance committee where it addressed the problem. A change in revenues does kind of change things here. Governments are aware at this time, for example, that although the goods and services tax, that despicable tax, generates a lot of money, it is not going to generate a lot of money if people do not pay it. If there are no transactions, the Government of Canada cannot collect the goods and services tax, which makes it pretty hard to get the money into your hands.
The government is now beginning to address crossborder shopping. It has not begun to address in a substantive way the fact that there is an underground economy growing in this country. It has not really looked at that one yet, but I suspect it will have to because that underground economy is growing more and more each day.
More and more people are seeing that what the Government of Canada is proposing these days is not reasonable. It is not fair. I would propose that that is the test that the government faces. The test is not writing this kind of formula down in a bill and passing the bill. That is not a test at all. It is nice and those are good intentions. It sounds like a workable formula it has going, but people across this country are saying: "That is not what you do. You may say that, but that is not what you do". It does not have very much to do with whether or not there is the generation of economic wealth in this country.
February 18, 1992	COMMONS
For example, if the government wants to target a number, 3 per cent, 5 per cent, 10 per cent or whatever, what does one do in the middle of a recession? Does one say: "Well, that is too bad but all of these companies are going to go bankrupt" , all of these individuals are going to suffer hardship and we will not help them because we have passed a law that says we cannot help them.
This week the government is going to be visited by some people from the agricultural industry again. I suspect very strongly that it is going to have to respond to them in some way. If there is a different conclusion to the GATT negotiations than the government anticipates,
I suspect it will have to respond to that.
If the Government of Canada decides it needs to go to war again, I suspect it will respond to that.
The only argument I am making is that this is a wonderfully simplistic, stupid notion. The attraction is that by some magic formula, members can dictate what will occur five years from now. I am arguing that it is not possible and that in a parliamentary system no one has ever pretended that it is. In a parliamentary system unlike a congressional system, the Minister of Finance gives his best guess.
I am an admirer of the congressional system. There are lot of things about it that I would like to see us do here in Canada. For example, I would like to see all of the numbers that are used in the preparation of the budget made available to the general public, not just to one minister of the Crown, so we could all make our judgments.
I noticed that in several legislatures across Canada and here to some extent, we are now beginning to accept that there is not a great deal of need for secrecy for this. Much of this can be on the public record and you do not have to turn to the Canadian public and say: "Trust us. We know you do not know". You could turn to the public record and say: "Here is what we know, compare that with what you know. Then you can compare my judgment as a Minister of Finance against yours as an individual taxpayer". That is reasonable.
I would like to see that information flow come into Canadian politics but it is not going to be accomplished by this bill.

Government Orders
Earlier on I asked that if there were penalty clauses here, would that suffice? It would answer one argument, the simple argument: Does this bill actually mean anything? Does this bill tell you something that you can take with some assurance? The bill lays out a formula that, to be as fair as I can, could be interpreted as the government's intentions in one avenue of financial matters over the next little while, but only one avenue. It lays out some restrictions that it intends to impose on itself if everything else remains normal.
Unfortunately in this world, everything else does not remain normal and one has to adjust. One did not anticipate a couple of years ago that we would be in a recession or depression such as we are in right now. People were spending money, governments were taking in revenue.
One would argue, and I suppose I would, that that is the time when government's ought to get really preoccupied with debt. When the revenues are really rolling in is a great time to start paying down your debts because you have the money to do it.
When times are hard is the time to put everything on hold for just a little while and think about other priorities, of municipalities and the things we need to do such as investing in the future of our children and of the infrastructure of our nation and trying to build those things. Those would be my priorities at that moment.
They are not mine in a personal sense. If you walk into any municipality in Canada tonight, they will give you a list of things that ought to be done in their municipality. They will tell you that if they are not done they do not have much hope of attracting new industry to their town and it is going to cost them more money in the long run if they do not do it. Therefore, this is not a secret and it is not my personal philosophy of life either. It is just reality.
There are some things I would recommend that the government consider. I notice that more and more people are starting to think about this. The government of Ontario today put the question to its own people, its own civil servants, explaining the the limits we are approaching and asking how we can do things and continue as normal and spend a little less money. We may have to be a little more creative in how we go about that.

February 18, 1992
Government Orders
I would think that members who have been here for a while would be the first to admit that there is virtually no incentive for any civil servant at any level of government, anywhere in Canada, to cut costs. Virtually none. That is a sad statement but I believe it to be true. There is no incentive for civil servants at any level to cut costs. They may get a gold star, they may get an award or they may have a free dinner when they receive that award but basically we have not set it up that way. We do not encourage our people to examine the programs in their own work place and we do not encourage those who would know them best on a day to day basis to examine them and begin that process.
In the private sector in many countries in the world they have begun to understand it is pretty important. People in the work place know what is going on. They can help us as executives, as managers, as governments, as corporations to examine what we are doing here. I would recommend that as being something that we ought to do.
I want to read one last section of this bill and I will close. This purports to be a straightforward bill, one which says there is the limit, if you spend over it, you have to take it from somewhere else. It is clause 11:
Inconsistent laws
In the event of any inconsistency between the provisions of this
Act and the provisions of any other law, the provisions of this Act
prevail unless that other law expressly states that it has effect
notwithstanding this Act.
In a nutshell that is what we are dealing with this afternoon. That is why I would not support it.

I suppose, Mr. Speaker, that all bills try to control spending and keep a lid on it, whether that can be done or not. My friend from the New Democratic Party is quite right, there are huge pressures from the Public Service and in departments to spend, spend, spend. They are there. There are huge problems from people wanting more, more and more from government. They are always there.
It would seem that my friend is saying: "You've got all these problems and you're trying to do this, but it won't work. Therefore, I won't support it because I won't help you to try to stop the spending". If that was the case, if the New Democratic Party feels that since it is tough to control spending, no controls on spending should be contemplated.
Is that the position of the New Democratic Party? Is it the position of the New Democratic Party that a bill which specifically says that on Tuesday next week the Minister of Finance can only present a budget having spending on programs of $100.9 billion, that notwithstanding that the minister can go and spend whatever he wants. Is it his party's position that we should not try to control the Minister of Finance and the government spending?
Is it his party's position to have a government say that by 1995-96, which is four budgets from now, the amount will be $111.25 billion and that it is unrealistic to increase spending because of all of these inflationary costs by $10.35 billion is wrong? Is that the New Democratic Party's view, that you cannot do anything about it, so do not do anything about it. Any effort to do anything about it is bad and therefore any help to control costs is bad so why not spend, spend spend and then eventually something else will happen? Is that the New Democratic Party's view?

At the risk of getting his blood pressure even higher, let me try to answer some of his questions. What the hon. member said is the traditional Progressive Conservative dance on the matter, that they are so smart and such great managers that they will handle debt like you would not believe. Unfortunately, that is true. It is a directional problem. The people of Canada were somehow misled to think that they would bring the debt in this country down. I think he is right. I do not ever remember them saying they were going to bring it down. They said they were going to handle it. They forgot to tell us they were going to take it up. That is the problem. There is just a little fine print there.
We are smarter in our old age. We are beginning to read not only what they say, but read some of the fine print. Let me try to tackle the hon. member's wild, spurious accusation that we are not cost conscience. Here is a thought for him.
I saw a poll that said most Canadians could not name most of the members in the cabinet. That tells me something. Maybe we do not need them. Nobody knows who they are. The people of Canada are not sure what they are doing. Maybe we could just do away with them. We should try that one on them for size.
February 18, 1992

I read the report of the commission on election expenses and reform the other day. That volume, in English and in French, hit my desk, put a dint in the desk. It is a pretty substantial volume. The committee might have been able to get its message out with a little less, shall we say, public relations. It was a very good effort, but that is the style of government these days. I prefer to attack the style and the substance of how governments spend money in Canada.
I have been on this topic for 20 years. It is a tough sell,
I admit it. Everybody in government is pretty comfortable and pretty insulated. I have noticed, though, that at many levels the government is starting to say: "When you wanted to talk cuts in government spending, we would call in all the department heads and they would write us a 20-page memo on how many workers outside ought to get laid off". I am impressed that some people are now saying: "Maybe we should sit down and do our job. Maybe the layoffs should not occur outside. Maybe they should occur inside. Maybe we should take a look at the top dogs and see if we should kick them off the porch for a day or two. Maybe that would be a unique thing".
These are kind of shocking revelations. I do not expect them to take hold right away, but when people talk to me about cuts in government spending, I am willing to talk about cuts in government spending, but all the way up and down the system let us have a long, thorough discussion about this. Do not tell me that you are going to solve the financial problems of Canada by keeping kids out of child care facilities. That is baloney and you know it.
Talk to me about the provision of services on a broad range and if we are going to get the broom out and sweep it and shake it, let us shake them all. That would be a different thing for us to do.

Mr. Speaker, I want to ask the member for Oshawa to return to a rather flip observation that he made against public servants because as I listened to it I found it kind of hard to take. He said that there was no one in the bureaucracy who had any incentive to reduce expenditures. I do not know how well he knows the bureaucracy, but I know it a little and I know it well enough to know that it is very responsive to the demands of the political system.
Government Orders
In the last decade there has been great pressure by the Canadian public put on its governments to tiy to control spending. I want to ask the member whether he would concede that a little of that filters through. When I say Public Service decision-makers I am not now talking about someone who supplies stationery at a counter when someone comes up and asks for it. I am talking now those who are entrusted and paid to carry out the will of the government inside the federal government. How can he say with such contempt that they have no incentive to reduce spending?

I note the word glib. I dislike that word because it is unfair to both the people who work for the Government of Canada and me. You can be unfair to me if you want, that is hardly of any concern to me, but to them it is unfair.
There are a number of people, for example, in the PS 2000 study who tried to make their voices heard. In the end, when they looked at the end result of that, they felt very strongly that they may have been consulted but nobody was prepared to listen. When I say sweeping from top to bottom, I mean that in the traditional sense from the top bureaucrat here on the Hill to the person who is looked at often on the bottom of the process out there. That is the person who may be able to give you the information you need to make the cuts that are sensible. Here is my cry. Why do you not listen to them once in a while? Do not feed them any more platitudes. Do not have any more conferences. Do not tell them what wonderful people they are. Forget the blue ribbons. Shut up and listen to what people across Canada, at all levels, have to say. That is a crime of which I myself am guilty because you have to learn that lesson first before you can hear their message.

One of the things I would like to ask the member about is his understanding of the problem that this government has put itself in. Here it is passing legislation that is reportedly binding a future government on expenditures when last year it went to the Supreme Court and had it rule that no government can bind future governments on expenditures
That was on the Canada Assistance Plan in which there was a specific law that spelled out expenditures. It was this government that went all the way to the Supreme Court challenging that law. The Supreme Court ruled that one government cannot bind, in fiscal

February 18, 1992
Government Orders
matters, a following government. How do you explain this whole bill which is based on this very premise that we are going to bind a government?

I think this bill might have had a chance of being accepted by the public at large if it had never heard of you or seen you or had any track record by which to judge the performance of this government. You might have been successful in convincing the public that you found the new wonder bread here that will feed the nation and solve all the problems. The problem is that the public has seen your act before. It has heard every song you have to sing. It knows that you have gone as far as the Supreme Court of Canada to retain the right to spend money as you see fit.
The public has seen you exercise billions of dollars in expenditures by means of Order in Council. It has seen every scheme that mankind has concocted during the course of this century for spending money pulled off by this government. To have you walk in with a bill like this in hand and try to plead that you are bom again is just too much for all of us.

Mr. Speaker, after disagreeing with the member for Oshawa about his attack on the Public Service, I think I would like to begin by agreeing very much with the tenor of the remarks that he just made. As he was speaking I was thinking of the old American saying, which I know must also apply in Canada, that you can fool all of the people some of the time, and some of the people all of the time, but you cannot fool all the people all of the time.
It is not the goal of this government to fool all of the people all of the time. The question is, as the member for Oshawa suggested, can it fool enough of the people enough of the time to be re-elected with the kind of performance it has had on the promise it made about deficit control? That has been a big issue in this debate and it underlies the significance of this bill. I was a member of the government and I remember very well the precise promise that it made. It is easy to remember because it was so simple. It said it was going to bring down the deficit.
Now, when questions are raised in the House about whether it has managed to bring the deficit down, it is amazing how long it takes to answer that question: "We are bringing the deficit down but it is not exactly the
deficit. We are not exactly reducing the cost of government but we are sort of reducing the cost of some programs of government. We are reducing the cost of our programs but we are not reducing the cost of the Liberal programs".
Although the deficit is going up, it is really going down if you look at it through the tortuous path that this government is using, the perspective it is offering the Canadian people, to try and get out of admitting failure on the promise it made in 1984 to reduce the deficit.
Some of the government members were serious when they made the promise. They came into office determined to reduce the deficit and they did not. Concerning the large deficit which they took over in 1984, which seemed to be large by historical standards of the time, they were busy reminding Canadians that we had increased the deficit more than ever since Confederation and we had been in office for 17 years or so. They proceeded in a short period of time to see that deficit doubled. They cannot go to the Canadian people again and say they are going to reduce the deficit again. They know a promise that they would make now would not be believed because of their abject failure to keep the promise they made in 1984.
If the government could not keep the promise that it made in 1984, not even some of the people, let alone enough of the people, would believe that in the next election it is going to be able to reduce the deficit.
I would like to say thanks to the policies of the Liberal finance ministers which had put us temporarily through some times which looked tough then, but which in perspective with the disastrous economic performance of this government are starting to look pretty good; even those years which we were not so proud of between 1980 and 1982. The government inherited an economy which began to boom. It presided over boom times.
I just heard the member, who is a former financial writer for The Toronto Sun, saying that it was going to take years of economic successes for the government to be able to reduce the deficit. Let us be realistic about it, he said. If this government is capable of reducing the deficit during boom times why did it not do it? Why did it have to pull out a slide rule and so much fine print to convince Canadians of the fact that it reduced the deficit
February 18, 1992

since it took office in 1984? The government did not reduce it. It saw the deficit more than double in a much shorter period than the period of deficit increases under the Liberals.
In many of the years when we were increasing the deficit it was the right financial posture to be taking. I am not saying it was right every year, but I will say that the Conservatives inherited some good times. Even during the course of the election the indices of good times started to appear. If they were really going to reduce the deficit, if the Canadian people who took them at face value were going to be honoured by the performance of the Conservatives, they would have done what they said they were going to do. They could have reduced the deficit and they did not.
This time they will not fool all the people. They might fool some of the people, but they have to ask whether enough people are going to be fooled by this bill into believing that we do not just have to rely on this government and its record of failure and disaster to reduce the deficit; we are going to have this fancy piece of legislation that is going to do the job for us.
If you do not believe in the government, which most Canadians do not, at least believe in Parliament which has enacted a piece of legislation, the Conservatives will tell on the hustings in the next election, that will tie the hands of the Minister of Finance, who was not bound by the promises that the government made during the election, who did not perform, who did not reduce the deficit, but who now will be constrained by this major piece of legislation to keeping the deficit down.
That is the spirit in which this legislation has to be examined. Is this legislation going to force the government to honour a commitment to reduce the deficit? This piece of legislation is an insult to the Canadian people and it is an insult to Parliament. What the government is saying is that this piece of legislation is worth taking the time that it is asking the elected representatives to take to study it and to celebrate it because it is going to do the job that the Minister of Finance could not do when he had boom times and when he brought in deficit budget after deficit budget, more than doubling the national debt. Now, because we cannot trust him, here is a piece of legislation that will have the stamp of Parliament on it which we can trust.
Government Orders
This piece of legislation comes from an honourable tradition, a tradition which has no relevance at all to the Canadian budgetary process. It comes from the United States in which the president brings forward or proposes a budget. There are cabinet secretaries who are responsible for fighting for the budget.
However, the system in the United States is different from ours. The budget cannot just go through because the administration wants it. In our system, the administration would have to resign if its budget did not go through. In the United States system, the administration knows that its budget will not go through. It knows that it is going to have to change the budget a lot, that the power in the legislative wing of the American congressional government system is going to be heard and that programs will emerge from the legislature, budgetary programs of a sort that cannot even be introduced by members of the opposition in this country. We cannot bring forward a money bill here unless we get the government to approve of it.
In the United States where this idea comes from, anyone can introduce a money bill and the budget that results is a matter of a compromise. As I mentioned a moment ago, our system is so different that the suggestion that this bill somehow or other constrains a Minister of Finance or constrains the budgetary process really is an insult. I would hope in political science classes and government classes across the country this bill is going to be picked out as a demonstration project of how a government can try to fool enough of the people enough of the time to get re-elected.
In our system it is as easy for the Minister of Finance to change this bill after it is enacted as it is for him to violate it, if he chooses to do so. The same minister who brings forward the budget brought forward this bill. It is a bill that stands in the name of the Minister of Finance. If it suits the Minister of Finance to live with this bill, he can live with it. If he prefers changing it, he does not have to negotiate that with the opposition. In taking his budget through Parliament he does not have to obtain our approval. He does not have to compromise with the undoubted power in the Congress to bring forward money bills of equal weight, of equal authority, and sometimes more than the authority of the administration of the day in the United States. The Conservatives are hoping that when people see this bill they will remember what happened in the United States where bills like this really do constrain a government and that they will think the same situation applies in our country. That is the story of this bill.

Government Orders
We sent a delegation from this Chamber to the United States to pick up ideas. I am in favour of that. It is very useful for us to see what is happening in one of the world's great democracies, in the congress of a superpower. They looked at this very type of restraint and I want to quote what they had to say about it.
The Conservative members of the committee who went there recognized themselves that however valuable this type of bill is in the American system, it is meaningless in the Canadian system. It is without meaning, without the possibility of altering a determined Minister of Finance who wants to have whatever budget he brings forward approved, in whatever form he brings it forward.
By the way, if he is unsuccessful in getting that budget through he has to resign. That does not happen in the United States. In the United States if they do not get their budget through they change it. However, in our system the Minister of Finance must have control of the House for his budget, or we get a new government.
This is what a parliamentary delegation said, supported by Conservative, Liberal and NDP members, when it studied this type of American constraint on the budgetary process. I would like to quote them. They said: "Budget control legislation is a distinctly American approach to problems arising in a quite unique legislative environment. Just because the American system might need such controls does not imply that the Canadian parliamentary system would necessary benefit from the same approach despite the fact that both countries face similar fiscal problems".
They face similar fiscal problems but the responsibility for our deficits is the sole responsibility of the government of the day, not of the Parliament. It is the sole responsibility of the Minister of Finance of the Conservative government that it has failed to keep its promise to reduce the deficit that was there in 1984. It might have some explanation for what it did, which might have been terrific. The Conservatives think it was terrific, but it certainly was not a fulfilment of their promise to make
the deficit less than when they found it; they made the deficit double what they found it.
The result of the economic performance of the government on the question of the deficit it will take to the Canadian people in the next election will be its deficit. It will not be the deficit of this Chamber. It will not be measures forced on it by the opposition in order to gain approval for its budget or for its programs. It cannot say any of that. It must take, in an accountable parliamentary system of government with a majority government, full responsibility for its economic performance. Every dollar of the deficit is one that is there only because it did or failed to do the measures that would have made it otherwise.
The Conservatives knew that back in 1982-83. They knew when they made the promise to reduce the deficit that people could accept it. The people knew that if they formed a majority government they would be able to have whatever deficit they decided to have. They blamed the Liberal government that preceded them for having the deficit that it had. We did not go around blaming the opposition for the deficit. We went around defending what we were spending the money on.
I have to remind people of something that is often forgotten, that is that many free, democratic countries like ours were also overspending in those years and were also putting off the worry about dealing with the deficit. I am not saying that dealing with the deficit was a top priority of ours. It was not. Delivering programs was a top priority of ours. We took account of the deficit but it was not our top priority.
However, it was the top priority of the Mulroney campaign team that made a promise to the Canadian people in 1984. We did not make it our top priority, but I am sure you may recall, Mr. Speaker, that they made it theirs. If they could not reduce the deficit in 1984, 1985, 1986, 1987, 1988 and 1989 when we had terrific economic performances in this country, they know that people will not believe it when they say they will will do it in the next mandate.
This fraudulent piece of legislation is brought forward to create the impression that somehow or other, if we do
February 18, 1992

not believe the Minister of Finance it does not matter because he is stuck with this legislation.
As I indicated in the question I asked of the member from Mississauga, it is as easy to deal with this restraint as it is to bring in a new expensive spending program. All they have to do in their 11-clause bill or their 300-clause bill or whatever is stick in one little clause saying that this new expenditure program which may be a fully justifiable program-I am not saying it will not be; I would like to see it before condemning it-gets the same treatment as the unemployment insurance program, namely it is outside the restraints which would otherwise apply.
This bill is no restraint at all on the government of the day. It is an attempt to make Canadian people, who I expect know better, believe that our system is more like the American system than it really is and that somehow or other the opposition or Parliament plays a role in determining what the contents of the budget are when we do not. We are bound if the budget does not go through to have an election on it.
I would urge the government, rather than trying to pull the wool over the eyes of my constituents one more time, to do some things that would really reduce the deficit.

Mr. Speaker, as one of the members of the finance committee that journeyed to Washington, I would like to pass some information on to the member for York Centre.
The member is suggesting that when Gramm-Rudman was first introduced in 1986 there were never any changes to it. In actual fact the finance committee learned that it had been changed three times because the fights among the president, the congress and the senate did not cause a smooth flow as the member would suggest.
When the bill came out in 1986 Gramm-Rudman suggested that the American deficit in 1992-1993 would be zero. They readjusted the targets two years later. In this fiscal year they are looking at a deficit of some $400 billion and getting worse because they have almost a $750 million loss in their savings and loans that they still have not figured out how they are going to pay for.
Government Orders
There were some problems with it. Gramm-Rudman allowed the politicians to adjust for inflation. If inflation went up 6 per cent their spending targets went up 6 per cent. That does not exist in the Canadian legislation.
The politicians made what I would say were conservative estimates on spending. When it came to projecting revenues they took a very liberal attitude and projected very high revenues. That made the deficit look smaller and at the end of the year when they tried to meet two moving targets it did not work. The minister here is trying to put it on the control side.
The Americans said: "You have a parliamentary system. You have one system. Maybe you do not need this type of legislation". Later on the report did say that this was probably good because it would focus on it. If indeed the Minister of Finance decides that he wants to change the targets, he has to come before Parliament and confess his sins as to why he might not meet these targets and where he is going to go. That would allow the opposition and all Canadians to understand.
It is quite clear that the government is not only setting targets but wants to establish targets. I do not know why the hon. member would be opposed to that.

Mr. Speaker, it is quite true that the Minister of Finance will have to appear before Parliament to amend this legislation if he wishes to present a budget that exceeds the spending limits in this bill or in any other legislation, but in any case, there is no such thing as a Minister of Finance who presents a budget and does not have the support of the majority of Parliament. It is not a matter of convincing the House but a simply a matter for the minister to decide. There is a difference.
I just read a book published in the United States, called Assembly of Whores, which describes the concessions and negotiations that are necessary in the United States for the administration to get its budget through Congress. Here, things are quite different. The government does not need us at all. In the past, the opposition's only right was the right to delay. During this Parliament, however, we even lost that right. We have no power except that of plying someone with questions for a certain time, condemning or criticizing, but everything is

February 18, 1992
Government Orders
still up to the government. In our system, every cent of our deficit, every single cent is the responsibility of the government. Not in the United States.

I am literally amazed that my friend would come to the House and say that the opposition cannot do anything about criticizing the government. It just does its own thing. Opposition members can go and talk on the street and make speeches, but really, they cannot change anything. The Minister of Finance has total control of everything.
You would almost wonder why they are here. The members have to realize here is a bill that specifically sets out that this Minister of Finance is going to produce a budget on Tuesday that will involve no more than $100.9 billion worth of expenditure on programs.
He does more than that. You have all sorts of targets. You can talk to the A-G. You can go after him day after day about the fact that he cannot run a country. He cannot be a minister. He cannot keep his promises. He cannot do this, that and the other. At least you have him pinned down.
Why would you not cheer this bill forward? I can criticize the bill. I am going to speak a moment or two, perhaps, if the Speaker recognizes me but surely the problem with the bill is that you hook the minister on the hook. Why would you not cheer that minister who decides to hang himself on his own petard here? Why would you not say this is wonderful? Now, we will get him.

Mr. Speaker, I am glad the hon. member asked the question. He asked why we want to be elected if we don't believe we can change the government's policy. I can inform the hon. member that we are not here to change the government's plans or to force it to change them. We do not have that power. We are here to provide the Canadians with an alternative. If the hon. member wants to give us a chance to show what that alternative is like, I would advise him to ask his colleagues to call an election, because that is what we are
waiting for. We are not waiting for the government to do what we want it to do. We are waiting to have a chance to get rid of them.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: Another question or comment? Resuming debate.

I always felt it was the duty of all of us in Parliament to make productive comments and suggestions as to how we, representing our constituents, could help make Canada work better.
The member for York Centre has suggested that you really can only do that in an election. You never make a concrete proposal or a policy or a way of handling things except in an election. You are just here to sort of collect your pay and criticize and harp, but never to make a policy suggestion. That is just unacceptable to me.
I would suggest that it should be unacceptable to all members and certainly to the public. Here we have a very senior member of Her Majesty's Loyal Opposition saying that there is nothing the opposition can do. There is nothing the opposition would put forward and there is no policy the opposition would have. Call an election and we will tell you what we are going to do. Huh.
This is an unacceptable attitude. It means that we have half of Parliament, the entire opposition, taking the position that it is really not here to make things better for Canadians. It is merely here to politic, get power and that is all that really matters.
Surely to goodness we are elected to try to bend, alter, change, develop and improve the lot of our electorate. We are not here just to make political gains. Let me deal with this particular piece of legislation. I am critical of this legislation because it tends to tie the government's hands and it can do very serious damage to any Minister of Finance.
The bill limits with a whole series of clauses the government's total spending on programs from 1991-92 through to 1995-96, a total of five years. Essentially the bill goes back to the last budget. In the next four years this government has to keep its spending down in increases on programs to less than $10.35 billion. That is a pretty serious limitation on the increase in program costs.
I suppose if the government is capable of keeping within its inflation targets, if things do not get out of



February 18, 1992

hand, it might be able to do that. But should inflation increase, the government is still stuck with that legislative limit on its spending. It is all very well to say the government could come forward with a bill and change that limit. Yes, it could. No government can bind another government and governments in this Parliament can always change laws. But think of the embarrassment, think of the problem, coming here as a government and saying that this is all you can spend and then saying at another time: "I'm sorry we couldn't keep within our targets. We could not manage as we said we could manage". What a terrible abject story of defeat.
Yet we have the opposition which does not want to see any controls on spending because they wants to spend, spend, spend. They never want to control spending. They want to spend. Therefore, they are opposed to this bill because it tries to limit spending.
They are very worried because they believe they might take over and then they would have to come to this Parliament and change the spending limits. They were not able to keep in track and keep spending in track.
Isn't that too bad. Let us find out when they vote on this bill how they vote. Are they prepared to limit spending? Are they prepared to say that all governments should spend? Are they prepared to say: "If you want to spend more on one program, then you will have to take the money out of another program?" Or are they prepared to carry on with their usual attitude: "We'll spend and we'll advocate more spending".
Day after day goes by. They stand up in Question Period and want this program or that program or this new add-on or benefit and they never control themselves. They do not want to see anybody control them. They want to be able without the criticism of the Auditor General to go ahead and spend without limit.
Sure there are some faults in the bill. Sure there are some exemptions in terms of an emergency where you could break the bill, but you would have to explain the emergency. In terms of farm relief you could break the bill, but you would have to show that was the cause. The fact is that the spending is set out in the blue book, hopefully filed next week by the President of the Treasury Board when he tables the estimates. The spending set out by the Minister of Finance in his budget for
Government Orders
program expenditure will be $100.9 billion and no more. In fact, it will have to be less than that.
It cannot be more and you cannot ever organize yourself to spend every last penny of your limited amount of budget to be audited by the Auditor General.
Has our Minister of Finance ever put the handcuffs on himself. But surprisingly the spenders do not want any handcuffs at all. They do not want any control on spending.
They talk about deficits. They say that this terrible government took over and the deficit was $180 billion or whatever. Now it is nearly $400 billion. They know, we know, the country knows that not one penny of that national debt increase from $180 billion to $400 billion is caused by program expenditure. It is caused by compound interest built up by a debt created by Liberal governments that had no limit on its appetite. When we took over their deficit was to be $37.5 billion and turned out to be well over $40 billion. We managed to crank it down to $37 billion.
Yes, the economy was booming but you were spending $16 billion more a year on programs than we took in in taxes, in programs. You had to borrow all this money, $30 million or $31 billion, and on top of that you had to borrow more money just to pay the programs.
Why didn't you stop the borrowing in 1985?

We did and if you had been here you would have seen that. You would have seen year after year program chops. What did we get? We got the crying, the weeping, the wailing, the gnashing of teeth of members of the Official Opposition saying, oh, you do not spend enough money.
Last week when speaking on the transfer program with respect to the CAP, my friend from Broadview-Greenwood-he is the spender. He is another spender. He is the guy who said that a 5 per cent increase in welfare and Canada Assistance Plan is not good enough, you have to have more, you have to have more. The inflation rate is down to 2 per cent but he thinks the 5 per cent increase is not good enough. Two and a half times inflation is not good enough for the member from Broadview-Greenwood. He wants to spend more and more. There is the kind of spender that you get in the Liberal Party. He

February 18, 1992
Government Orders
does not want controls on spending, he wants the right to spend, spend, spend, spend and no controls.
I want to spend on retraining.

There we are, we have now got the admission. Mr. Speaker, we now have the admission. He wants to spend but he does not say where he is going to get the money to spend. You know where he is going to get the money to spend? He will tax more or borrow more. Awful easy to borrow, not very good to tax. He wants to borrow more so really when it gets down to it these people have no desire to cut back on their appetites. They want to put this country in the hands of the IMF.
Let us not cry about deficits because you will never control deficits until you control spending. The minister has produced a bill and I can tell you I found a lot of imperfections in it. I think it should go to committee and perhaps be tightened up a bit.
Can you imagine an Official Opposition complaining about deficits but not prepared to do anything about spending even when the minister puts it in a bill? The minister says: "I will only spend $100.9 billion next year on programs and I am limited to that. If I spend more you have got me". Members opposite say: "We do not want to get you, Mr. Minister, we want you to spend more because every day in Question Period we are going to ask you to spend more. Every bill that comes along to cut spending we are going to want you to spend more. Oh, we do not want to say your hands are tied".
Yes, sir, we need a lean, mean machine in this country to make this country grow. We need to build a country and get rid of our debts and make sure we are competitive. We cannot stand any more Broadview-Greenwood giveaways.

Mr. Speaker, there is absolutely no way I could let my friend from Mississauga South get away with that. There is one thing that we say on this side of the House about the member from Mississauga South and it is that during the last election campaign, he had the courage to stand up and tell the people of Canada that the GST or the value added tax, as we were calling it at that time, was going to be a $10 billion gouge from Canadian taxpayers, when
the then minister of finance from Etobicoke said that this GST was going to be revenue neutral.
I enjoy engaging in debate with the member from Mississauga South because he is on the mark many times. He was on the mark with his idea of capping interest rates on credit cards in his private member's bill which I supported in this House, but his government colleagues would not get behind him when everybody in the country was supporting him.
The problem with this bill is the fact that it is filled with loopholes. It is filled with opportunity for the government because if a reason for additional funding requirement comes along, it can always be referred to the emergency clause in this bill.
With all the best intentions of the member for Mississauga South, there is no way that the people of Canada are going to believe that this bill is anything other than smoke and mirrors and a diversion from the fact that the debt in this nation has doubled in the last few years and in spite of it doubling, we still have an economy where the people are in deep pain. We talk about retraining here, yet one cannot get retrained. We talk about hope. We are looking for it.
My question to the member is this. Does he not think that it is a bit cynical to say that we on this side of the House are not concerned about the deficit and debt, that we are just spenders when it was his government in the last five years that had 32 tax increases including the GST which he himself did not support during the last election.

I do not want to disabuse of my friend. I spoke in favour of the goods and service tax or the value added tax in the election. I spoke in favour of it before the election and I want to tell him and his colleagues in the Liberal Party, on two occasions, unanimously in the House of Commons and in the finance committee endorsed that tax.
I have just been handed the financial results of the country for the first eight months of this year. If you want to take a look at spending, you will find that program spending as of the end of the first eight months was $71.24 billion. This bill means that for a 12-month period, the government will only be able to spend $97.2 billion. Government Orders
the feelings that we, as Canadians, can look to from this government and future governments with respect to where this country is going?

Mr. Speaker, I think the member from Thunder Bay made a very important point. When we are spending 37 cents or 36 cents of every dollar we take in tax on interest, we have precious little money available for day care, senior citizens, training and all of the things that we would like to have. That seriously impairs the ability of this government and provincial governments to some extent that depend on our transfers and municipal governments that depend on transfers from their province to perform those things that Canadians want.
The most serious thing that we can do, and this House has that challenge, is to get our financial house in order, get our debts down and stop spending the money we are spending so that we will not have to borrow, so we will not have to pay that huge portion of the revenues of the country to the bond holders.
This is a bill designed to tiy to do that. It is not a perfect bill. It is a bill trying to force government to come to reality in terms of its spending. When we in this House vote money, we in effect authorize the spending of money. What we have to do is say: "Well, you can only tax so much. The only other way to get at your problem is eliminate or cut back on your spending".
I do not think we are very good at that. I think we make a mistake in committees of the House when we have the estimates before us in not cross-examining and cutting back on some of those estimates. I think we ought to be passing resolutions and cutting back estimates all the time. We have an obligation to do that. Surely we have an obligation to put some over-all controls on where we spend money. This is an attempt to do that and I would ask the opposition to support that attempt.

speakerposition: Deputy Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have sat here for the last little while listening to some of the comments of my colleagues, especially my colleagues from across the way. I always have to remind them and anyone else who needs reminding that we do live in a parliamentary democracy.
Parliamentary democracy says that if a government wins the majority of votes that it is in control, that it can

February 18, 1992
Government Orders
vote whatever amounts of money it needs. It can pass pretty well whatever laws it wishes. It need not listen to opposition if it does not want to and more often than not it does not. Therefore, it is in control. From the day it is elected, it is in control.
This bill says to me that this Conservative government is admitting to the people of Canada that it has failed. It has been totally incapable of controlling its own spending. Imagine. This is the government in power. It has its own finance minister, its own cabinet, its own meetings and all of the finance officials work for it. It is saying to the Canadian public: "We cannot control our program spending. We cannot do it. We have to pass a law". That must be the reason why it would bring forward a bill such as this. What other reason could there be?
There might be another reason. There just might be. I think it is another very valid reason. The government has realized that it is going to lose the next election. It is over folks. Too bad, it is gone. Therefore, it has decided that it will try and leave a legacy of conservatism, somewhere, somehow, by passing a bill trying to control what is going to happen next time around.
It may be a good idea, but I do not happen to agree with it. I happen to believe that the only way to control spending is by the will of the people, the will of the people who are elected and the will of the people who form the government.
If you have to pass laws which have absolutely no teeth, if your minister comes in on Tuesday with a budget that is over the limit that has been set here-this is not a bill yet-the answer will be: "Well, it is not an act of Parliament yet, so we really do not have to follow it". What measure is there to make the minister and the government follow this particular plan? There is none. Who is going to send the Minister of Finance or the cabinet to jail? What is going to happen? Can you do it? Can this bill do it? No, it cannot. So why bother, except to fool people.
This is the same group of people who got elected in 1984 by saying: "We are going to battle the deficit". In 1984 they said: "Imagine, if we continue spending the way the Liberals have been spending, by the year 1992 there will be a debt of over $400 billion". They said that in 1984. Imagine that. They have been in since 1984 and
do you know where the debt is now? Over $400 billion. What happened to all these plans? They always have these fantastic projections and these great plans, but they cannot seem to follow through on any of them.
Let us stop playing games. This is another attempt at game-playing, at trying to pretend that: "Hey, we have now seen the light. Hallelujah".
When you look at this piece of legislation it says very clearly: "The minister may in a budget for a particular controlled fiscal year propose program spending for the particular year that exceeds the spending limit for that particular year". He can do that if he wants.
There is another one here that says: "The minister may present a budget for a control fiscal year that proposes program spending for any particular control fiscal year that exceeds the spending limit for that particular year". It goes on to say under what conditions and all the rest of it.
What no one has explained to me is why we pick 3.8 per cent. In the draft legislation that had been before the finance committee somebody had proposed 3 per cent. I guess it just sounded like a nice neat amount. Now it is 3.8 per cent. Why should it be 3.8 per cent? Why should it not be 0 per cent? Why should it not be a decrease? Why should it not be 2 per cent? You have limited the Public Service to no increase, but you are saying that now the magic number is 3.8 per cent. Let me see. The proposed limits would allow program spending increases of 3.8 per cent in the fiscal year ending March 31, 1993,
3.2	per cent in fiscal year 1994, 3.2 per cent in fiscal year 1995,; and 3.6 per cent in fiscal year 1996. It then goes on to give the actual dollar amount.
What kind of divine intervention has come into their minds to tell them that this is the number?. This is it. After all, the interventions that they have had in the past have not come through. They certainly have not followed what was in their proposals. We have heard for many years about how they were going to tackle the deficit, and it was going to be gone. We are still way over $30 billion in terms of the deficit.
I ask you again: Why that particular rate? Why not a lower rate? The worst thing with setting a limit is it becomes the number you aim for. I do not happen to believe that we should aim for this number. I think we
February 18, 1992

have to do the best that we can with the moneys we have, and hopefully there could be no increases if necessary. If it were possible, would it not be a lot better than 3.8?
I ask the question. I do not happen to be one of the lucky ones who sits on that side of the House and has the moral authority to set the amount at whatever for whatever reason.
We have to remember one other thing. If you can recall, I say one of the reasons for bringing this bill forward is that this government realizes that it is finished, it is going to lose the next election, it is over, too bad. We are now into the last year of this government's mandate.
We hope.

speakerposition: Deputy Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
Well, we know. Even it is admitting it with this bill. It is over and done with.
One of the things that is happening is that this bill would allow the government in a budget to propose spending that would exceed the limit for a particular year and then to say how in the next two years it is going to make it up. You tell me how a government which is not going to be here after the next election can propose this. On Tbesday the Minister of Finance can come in with all kinds of neat ideas and then afterward they can say: "Oh, oh, blame the party that came in and took over from us. It did not follow. We said it should spend this much less because we overspent this year". It does not make a lot of sense to me.
I am wondering, why now? If the government is that interested, why did it not bring in this kind of a bill in 1988, or in 1985? That was the time to start really paying down the deficit. It tried, but not very hard, I must say. It was not the biggest effort on the part of anyone. What I am saying is that the Conservative government lacks any kind of direction. It has a bottom line mentality-bottom line, bottom line, bottom line.
I have news for this Conservative government. We are not a business. We look after the interests of Canadians. Yes, it is good to have sound fiscal management, it is very good. But you must not forget that you are dealing with the lives of people. You may complain about what Liberal governments did in the past, but if you get right down to it, if it were possible to work the economic
Government Orders
theories, in bad times governments spend and in good times governments create surpluses to pay back the times that were bad. If anyone had bothered to follow that principle from 1984-85 on, we should have no deficit at this time.
Oh, but no, we were a lot more interested in having a gay old time. We increased taxes in some of the most prosperous years that this country has ever known. We increased them in 1985, 1986 and 1987. What kind of fiscal policies did we bring in? Did we really try to battle the deficit?
We said we would, and it did come down somewhat but not enough. It did not come down enough when you consider the growth of the economy and the kind of prosperity that we had at that time.
Now when we are at a time of depression again, there are no moneys to help people. Now there are only spending restraints. Whose fault is it? You are very ready to blame past governments and I am now very ready to start blaming you for your mismanagement.
Perhaps if you had managed a little bit more wisely, we would not be in this position we are today. The idea behind all of this nonsense is to try to hoodwink Canadians into thinking that you are finally going to do something, like they do in the States.
Well, Gramm-Rudman in the States did not work. There are always ways around and it is still not working in the States. I like to think of the States as a tax increase waiting to happen. It has not faced its deficit problems. The laws that were passed and the amendments did not prevent it from running up huge deficits.
There are always emergencies. There are always wars or high unemployment. There is always something, so you have to look at everything. You cannot just set yourself some kind of a target. If you want to do that when you form the next government, if you ever do again, go right ahead.
There are many other things that are very loose about this bill and some of it is the tax expenditure loopholes. Obviously, there are times when the economy needs stimulating, and you can use a tax loophole. A tax discount can be given if you promise to invest in certain shares of certain companies. I can do all kinds of things. This does not stop that.

This does not say whether it is the right way or the wrong way. This just looks at $100 billion in year 1993. What happens if we expand the economy? Why $100 billion? Why not $80 billion that year?
I am just curious about who is the guru who came up with the magic figures and is trying to write a budget for the next five years. I have no idea who is the guru, and I am not particularly impressed with him by the way.
You talk about there being nobody on this side of the House who is fiscally responsible. I have news for you. Many of us are.
I was once a member of a municipal council, a regional council and we brought in some very different types of proposals. One of them was a pay-as-you-go proposal. I will go back to to 1988 before the last election. That would have been a time to bring in tougher monetary policies. That would have been a time to start curbing inflation, but no, no. The people across the way were far more interested in winning elections, so they went on a wild spending spree.
What is to stop them from doing that now? What is to stop you from doing that now? Who knows? They will do it again. They will find a way around it. That is what they did in 1988. Not only that, but in 1988 they said to Canadians: "We are going to give you a tax break. We are going to give you a tax break". So they gave everybody a tax break.
It was great for getting re-elected. It did absolutely nothing for what was coming. They did not even get elected because of that. They got elected because of the free trade and the massive advertising by a third party that scared a number of people into voting and that is a very dangerous thing. If they had been a little bit more conscious of doing the right thing, they still might have won that election and we would not be in this-

is happening to our fanners. We hear about what is happening in the resource sectors. We hear about what is happening in southern Ontario in terms of the manufacturing sector. All these problems cannot be dealt with by using a bottom line mentality. It just does not work.

Mr. Speaker, I am delighted to be given the opportunity to attempt to seek more information on a couple of questions that I had raised previously.
Some of my colleagues will recall that I asked the Minister of State for Youth, when he announced his program for school dropouts, whether or not comprehensive evaluation programs had been undertaken, had been planned or were about to be initiated so that we could determine whether there would be more people working as a result of this initiative.

My colleagues will perhaps recall that there was a very similar supplementary question asked of the government's literacy initiative. I will ask it in both official languages of Canada to be absolutely sure that I am understood. You began two projects. Good, no problem with that. Now, did you set
February 18, 1992

up evaluation mechanisms so that we can know whether or not this extra spending means that fewer or more young people have been able to find work and whether fewer or more Canadians can do arithmetic, read and write more easily than they could before. speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, on behalf of the Minister of State for Youth, I am pleased to tell you about the plans to evaluate the government's initiative for fighting the school dropout problem.
It has been clearly established that a higher level of education leads to better jobs.
The government is preparing to evaluate the program part of "School First". "School First" is in three interrelated parts and is meant to reduce the school dropout rate, which is about 30 per cent in Canada.
First, the part to mobilize the various interest groups seeks to involve business people, unions, educators, social workers, non-government agencies, parents and young people themselves in helping to find solutions for the school dropout problem.
The public awareness part is intended to provide the public with information on the school dropout situation in Canada and its harmful effects on our economic prosperity.
Adjournment Debate
Finally, the program and services component is to support direct and indirect approaches to encourage young people at risk to remain in school.
The government is working with the provinces to develop common methods to determine to what extent the dropout rate is reduced by our initiatives together with those of the provinces.

Mr. Speaker, tonight I want to discuss a crucial issue that is having a major impact on Canadian society. The issue is hard core pornography and the degradation and violence inflicted on women and children.
Many violent crimes, including wife battering and the sexual abuse of women and young children, can be traced to readily available hard core pornography.
Studies on the effects of hard core pornography have been consistent in their findings. The studies conclude over and over again that pornography affects men's attitudes about sexual aggression toward women.
Hard core pornography is dangerous. It exploits innocent children and women. I was shocked to learn that children are one of the primary consumers of pornography. A national survey recently showed that 38 per cent of male and female children between 11 and 17 years old reported watching pornography at least once a month.
A later survey of grade 9 students by Professor Check showed that 80 per cent of them had watched pornography. The average age of first exposure to pornography was 12.
The pornography industry is powerful, aggressive and committed to the exploitation and subordination of women and children.
Detective Sergeant Gary Colangelo heads up the morality branch for the York Regional Police Force. Pornography is one issue his branch investigates.
The one adult-only video store in Markham, which opened fairly recently, had copies of two videos that members of the morality branch decided were pornographic. The two videos have since been removed from the shelf.
A Criminal Code provision currently makes production, distribution and possession for distribution of obscene publications a crime. There is presently no legal

February 18, 1992
Adjournment Debate
definition of pornography. Instead, offensive materials are defined by the imprecise term "obscene", making it difficult for Canadian police officers to enforce.
Police officers insist they can make little headway in reducing the widespread incidence of hard core pornography if the federal government does not introduce effective and forceful legislation.
Several months ago I wrote to over 40 ministers and rabbis in the riding about the problem of hard core pornography. I explained my plans and invited members of their congregation to have friends and neighbours sign a special petition I prepared to call on the government to eliminate the production and distribution of hard core pornography.
Members of several churches participated, including St. Andrew Presbyterian Church, Unionville Alliance Church, Thornhill Presbyterian and Gormley Missionary Church.
In conclusion, I am calling on the Minister of Justice to introduce a strong bill to curb pornography. Its implementation is crucial to our nation's already fragile moral fabric.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member for Markham-Whitchurch-Stouffville has asked the government to address the issue of hard core pornography by bringing in strong legislative measures to conquer this problem.
This is a matter of great concern to the hon. member and I would like to point out to the House that the hon. member has been one of the champions of this cause, I believe, ever since his entry into federal politics in 1984.
He is aware, I am sure, that many Canadians share his view that the availability of such materials is a contributing factor to violent crimes, including incidents of family violence and the sexual abuse of children and women.
The question of pornography, especially violent pornography, and whether it is associated with crimes against women has been the subject of numerous studies.
As well, the hon. member is aware that in the last few years the federal government has made several unsuccessful attempts to amend the criminal legislation regulating pornography. The most recent attempt to change the law was Bill C-54, which died on the Order Paper in 1988. Bill C-54 was contentious and was condemned by a number of groups, including literary and arts communities, libraries and civil liberties associations. However, despite this controversy, I believe there is unanimous support for stronger legislation regarding pornography involving children and violent pornography.
As has been stated previously in this House, the government intends to introduce legislation during this session of Parliament directed at prohibiting child pornography to prevent the sexual exploitation of children and to protect them from harm. I know that will receive the support of the honourable member and of all members of the House.

Mr. Speaker, in a recent statement to the House, I called on the federal government to listen to the pleas of small business people. I called on the government to abandon its high tax policies such as increases in unemployment insurance, policies which are crippling our small business.
Small business growth was a major contributor to our last economic recovery in the 1980s. Unfortunately, small business, along with all Canadians, has lost total confidence in the ability of this government to handle this recession. The symptoms of this lack of confidence are obvious. There is simply a lack of consumer spending. We have an unemployment rate of 10.4 per cent. Our bankruptcy rate continues to increase; it is up 37 per cent from 1990. Canadians are reluctant to spend due to the uncertainty of their job status.
In my province the unemployment rate remains high, at 16.9 per cent. There is little sense of recovery at this moment in my province of Prince Edward Island. The unemployment rate continues to increase every month. The bankruptcy rate increases. Potato farmers have suffered some of their toughest times in our history. Our dairy, poultry and egg farmers are watching nervously as

this government appears to be weakening its commitment to strengthen article XI and preserve our supply management system. Free trade and world restructuring appear to be leaving Canada behind.
