The list goes on and on. That is a list of recent announcements in Atlantic Canada and it alone represents over 4000 jobs.
The Canadian Federation of Independent Business said in a recent brief: "The missing link is a resurgence of business and consumer confidence, both of which are powerfully affected by the actions of government".
The Atlantic Provinces Economic Council is calling for direct stimulus from the government in the form of increased spending on infrastructure projects. Many of the provincial premiers have called on the federal government to take action to stimulate a rebound in consumer confidence.
Our leader has outlined an economic plan that would help speed up the recovery. I would like to note that the plan of my party does not call for a wholesale increase in the deficit. In fact, the plan defines where the funding will come from to implement the proposals.
It is time for a concerted effort to get the economy moving again. Next Tuesday's budget must provide the needed boost in confidence to get consumer spending moving again and to put Canadians back to work.
Next Tuesday, Canadians will be looking to the budget for hope. For the sake of all of us, I certainly hope that this budget-

speakeroldname: Mr. Jack Shields (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Employment and Immigration
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my hon. friend in her question to the minister and in her comments tonight indicated that the unemployment rate is very high in her province of Prince Edward Island.
Indeed, unemployment is too high in Canada from coast to coast. We all recognize that. For her to go on and indicate that this is a made-in-Canada recession that we have come through-and signs are coming
Adjournment Debate
forward that we are coming out of the recession, we know that-is totally misleading to the House.
One of the things that I would like to point out is that if my hon. friend was to read the headlines of newspapers from the United States, from Germany, from France, from Holland and from Great Britain, if she did not know which newspaper she was looking at, she would find that the headlines and comments are basically the same in all of those countries.
The thing I am trying to point out is that this is a world-wide recession that we are going through and Canada is coming out. Canada cannot come out of this recession as my hon. friend has suggested and wholesale intervene in the economy. What we have to do is get our deficit and debt under control.
As soon as we are able to do that, then the world investor confidence creates the inflow of capital into this country that is so desperately needed to create the kinds of jobs that my hon. friend is talking about.
Once international confidence has been restored in the Canadian economy-and we have seen that in the past and we will see it more after the budget-and once that happens, then we will see consumer confidence also take hold. When that happens, jobs will be created in this country and we will be on the road to prosperity the way we should be.

Mr. Speaker, on November 6 I raised a number of questions in the House about the three Orders in Council which the government introduced in the past and announced publicly on October 30, 1991.
The Orders in Council consented to the transit through Canadian waters of U.S. and British nuclear-propelled vessels, consented to U.S. and British vessels that are capable of carrying nuclear weapons to pass through Canadian waters and visit Canadian ports, and consented as well for U.S. nuclear-propelled submarines to pass submerged through Canadian waters at the Dixon entrance. The answers given by the Associate Minister of National Defence were, I submit, completely unsatisfactory.
In 1991, the Department of National Defence proposed that Orders in Council be used to consent to these various visits and passages through Canadian waters. Under the federal EARP guidelines, this request went to Environment Canada and a memorandum was prepared

February 18, 1992
Adjournment Debate
dated August 28, 1991 by David Barnes of FEARO, the government office that is responsible for reviewing these proposals.
In the course of the memorandum, which was approved by the director general of operations at FEARO, he said: "National Defence's reluctance to conduct an initial assessment under the EARP needs to be questioned. It has come to our attention that the United States conducted an environmental review with extensive public involvement of an acoustic testing facility for nuclear submarines to be located at Behm Canal, Alaska, notwithstanding the obvious defence-related sensitivity of that facility. If such public consultation was possible for the United States in that situation, should it not be possible for Canada to do the same in this case before National Defence takes its decision?"
The recommendation of FEARO was that EARP applies to the decision to authorize the port visits and that National Defence is the initiating department. In the view of FEARO the process should be followed.
The decision of this government to go by way of Order in Council avoids a public process which is essential to the confidence that the people in my constituency of Victoria have in the visit into our waters of nuclear powered vessels and vessels which are capable of carrying nuclear arms.
If any other member of this House contemplated the building of a nuclear power plant in his or her constituency without a single public inquiry into the event, there would be hell to pay. That is precisely what this government has consented to in this case.
It is this which the people of Victoria and the people of our region object to. As a result of the government action, a lawsuit has been launched to challenge the government's opinion. It is totally inappropriate when the government has the kind of advice it has from FEARO that it should put citizens in this country through the requirement of testing these positions in court.
I call on the government to say today that it is willing to have a public review of the environmental consequences. The government says there are no problems here as a result of 20 years of looking at this. I say the time has come for the government to come out publicly
and present its case and to give the people of Victoria and of our region an opportunity to speak on it.

speakeroldname: Mr. Patrick Boyer (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of National Defence):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Defence
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the member for Victoria raises a very significant and sensitive issue, the passage of nuclear propelled submarines through Canadians waters. The Canadian government policy is very clear. It is founded on two principles: first, the preservation of Canadian sovereignty and second, the security of our environment.
I do not accept the interpretation that the member for Victoria is placing with such vehemence that the government is refusing to have any hearings into this whole issue because pursuant to the June 1990 cabinet agreement on the environmental assessment on policies to which he has referred, National Defence conducted a review of the potential environmental impact of the policy to allow these visits that he is referring to on our west coast.
Environment Canada reviewed the assessment at the request of National Defence and External Affairs. Environment Canada was satisfied with the conclusion that environmental impacts of these visits would be insignificant. Moreover, the results of those inquiries are public and the documentation to which the member refers, as if it was some document he had obtained in an amazing fashion, are public documents.
This is something that I can certainly say as a parliamentarian, and as a member of this government, we want to have the public involved in. We want the Canadian people to be satisfied that the risks that are potentially there are being addressed. That is why for 20 years since the previous Liberal government initiated this policy in 1967 about port visits, we have done these things.
We have monitored. In fact it is the monitoring program that has brought to our attention just last Ihesday the collision of a U.S. submarine allegedly in Russian waters with a Russian submarine. These things are significant. We are keeping a close watch on it. The public interest is certainly being served as it must continue to be.

Mr. Speaker, on February 11, just a couple of days ago, I rose in this House to ask the government a question relating to the Western Grain Transportation Act, the decision of the Supreme Court on the Oldman case and the oppor-
February 18, 1992

tunity that it gave to the federal government to be involved in an environmental impact assessment of possible changes to the Western Grain Transportation Act.
I was looking for a response from the government that would indicate that it was going to take its previous statements and the decision of the court seriously and announce that an environmental impact study would be announced. I am quite concerned that if past practices are anything to be concerned about, then Canadians have to worry about the future of grain transportation in Canada and the impact that changes like that would have on our environment.
The question was posed to the Minister of Transport and the supplementary to the Minister of the Environment because, according to the Supreme Court decision, the Minister of Transport would be primarily the minister of responsibility here, given that any changes to the act would be initiated through the Minister of Transport.
My concern stems from the fact that the Minister of Agriculture has begun a process of public meetings throughout western Canada in which farmers and interested community individuals can discuss the future of grain transportation in Canada and possible options for change to the Western Grain Transportation Act.
Obviously, if there are options on the table for change, then there must be consideration being given by the government to make some changes. The majority of producers on the prairies who have attended those meetings have indicated that they want no change; the Western Grain Transportation Act, the Crow benefit, the status quo, must be maintained in order to facilitate the orderly transporting of grain to port from the elevators. They have called for some efficiencies in the system, such as ensuring that the lowest possible cost from the farm gate to the port be considered.
They have expressed some concern about the environment. Recently in the green plan the government indicated that policy decisions of government such as changes in legislation should be subjected to an environmental assessment. Most recently, on January 23 of this year, the Supreme Court of Canada indicated that an
Adjournment Debate
environmental assessment is a planning tool that is now regarded as an integral part of sound decision making. The earliest part in the process should be the environmental impact assessment.
I want the government to carefully consider the environmental consequences of changing the Western Grain Transportation Act before it takes steps to change the act. That would be the sound decision-making process. I feel that perhaps the opposite circumstance is being followed, that the decision to change the act has been made and later an environmental impact assessment would be followed.
I do not know the impact on the environment as a result of changes to the Western Grain Transportation Act, but I am concerned because grain moving by truck instead of on the rail would be a significant environment detriment.
I ask for clarification, and more important, I ask that the environmental impact assessment be done.

speakeroldname: Mr. Patrick Boyer (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of National Defence):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Defence
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the member for The Battlefords-Meadow Lake has raised an important issue here relating to an issue that goes back through the whole development of the Canadian west, and that is the movement of grain.
When I was a newspaper reporter in his constituency, back in 1966 at the News Optimist in North Battleford, I learned a lot about the history of grain handling in the west. I hear him say, although he is a member of the New Democratic Party, that he is standing four square to maintain the status quo. I also hear him saying that he is concerned that public meetings are being held in western Canada relating to this issue. I would have thought, and it is certainly the view of the government, that consulting with the people is a very appropriate thing to do for any government looking at the long term interests of Canadian wheat producers and, moreover, other industries and activity that should be developing in western Canada such as greater milling and activity relating to the agricultural products in the west rather than having them shipped to my constituency where there are a lot of milling operations, bakeries, and so on.

February 18, 1992
Adjournment Debate
The maintenance of the status quo is not necessarily in the best interests. That is why this government is looking at and set up in 1990 the transportation committee on agrifood policy. That review has looked at changes to the Western Grain Transportation Act on land use, land values, transportation, and the environment as well. The green plan applies here. That is why this environmental impact is being looked at and remains a cornerstone of this current review. No decision is going to be made until this process of discussion, these meetings, are concluded. I want to reassure the hon. member from The Battle-fords of that.
Certainly it is not beyond the capacity of the people in this country to meet and discuss these problems, to look
at the environment, the issue that lies behind that, which is maintenance of the status quo, and in this case perhaps even using the environmental argument as a means of maintaining the status quo. There are big issues at play here. That is why the government is taking a leadership role in seeing that they are addressed in conjunction with the producers and the citizens of western Canada.
